utterances: NPR's Quil Lawrence visited a base where new pilots are training.
The airstrip outside the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk has a few advantages for training pilots.
There aren't as many dust storms up north and it's a quick flight to the Kurdish region, where almost no one on the ground tends to shoot at you.
(Soundbite of landing gears)
Watching the two-seater prop planes come back from practice, Lieutenant Colonel Nathan Browner(ph) nods in approval at a good landing, or even a decision to pull out and try again.
The pilots here are beginners, but that's a good thing, says Browner, because what's left of the Iraqi Air Force is getting over the hill.
Only 19 of them are under the age of 40.
And this is in a country with an average life expectancy of 47 years.
So, you tell me what the longevity of an air force like that is.
During the Iran-Iraq War, there were frequent dog fights, but the Iraqi Air Force sat out the 1991 Gulf War and then it languished.
Young pilots from the 1990s are now just about ready to retire, says one veteran, Abu Mustafa(ph).
The new air force is for the lieutenants, not for us.
There's more change because in the past, we train the fighter.
Now, we train only instruments on the navigation.
No matter how nice the equipment is, it's still just a little one-prop Cessna 172, says Abu Mustafa.
When I was lieutenant, I flew the (unintelligible).
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yes.
Now, the lieutenant, they flew Cessna 172.
Colonel Browner readily admits that it's hard to get any pilot excited about a prop plane after he's flown a Russian MIG jet fighter.
And they're thinking, okay, well, we used to have MIG-25s.
What are you going to do for us?
And we came in and we said, well, you know, we think propeller-driven aircrafts is really where you need to be going these days.
And they looked at that and they said, that's not very sexy.
In fact, some former Iraqi pilots haven't rejoined the new Iraqi Air Force that the Americans are standing up for just that reason.
One ex-fighter pilot, interviewed in Baghdad, said he thought it was insulting to fly one of the little Cessnas.
Unidentified Man #1: We have many bases now, very good bases, but we don't have airplane.
You know, this is a new plane, this is prop not supersonic or subsonic.
I fly by this plane before, 20 years ago.
It's a very old plane.
The ex-pilot said he believes the Americans were scared to give Iraq fighter jets.
But according to Browner, the reasons are more practical: jet fighters need newer, cleaner hangars and runways.
And for fighting insurgents, Iraq doesn't really need fighter jets.
I'm Ed Gordon, and this is NEWS & NOTES.
Everyone, when you think about air power, the thing that probably comes to mind is fighters hitting ground target.
But when you're talking about engaging successfully in the counterinsurgency, you're really talking about more non-kinetic forms of airpower.
For example, a prop plane can loiter for a much longer time over a target gathering intelligence.
They're cheaper and they can land on the dilapidated runways all over Iraq.
(Soundbite of a propeller)
As they return from a sortie, it's clear some of the new pilots get it, like a 26-year-old from Baghdad who gave his name as Lieutenant Hidar(ph).
Everything (unintelligible) step-by-step.
We're looking in the future.
I have to (unintelligible) now we have this aircraft.
Lieutenant Hidar performed well enough that he has been made an instructor, something he said would have been unthinkable for someone from a modest family, like his, in the old Iraqi Air Force.
My father before hoped for me to be a pilot.
Also, he wanted to be a pilot, but he didn't get a chance.
Another young instructor from the southern city of Kut has a more visceral connection to flying.
It's very awesome.
I don't believe they (unintelligible) to fly.
Mohammed Habib says he could hardly wait to get back from his breaks to log more hours flying.
He says he knows that the U.S.
is supposed to be leaving Iraq, but he'd like them to stay for six or eight more years, long enough to teach him how to fly the massive prop cargo planes, like the C130, or even fighter jets.
Quil Lawrence, NPR News, Kirkuk.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Who knows what would have happened if Geoffrey Chaucer had not written ""The Canterbury Tales"" in English?
After all, French or Latin would have been more likely for the time.
Who knows what impact that would have had on the great stream of English literature that then flowed from Britain, or on the adoption of English as the language of America and of the world?
All week, Rob Gifford is retracing Chaucer's steps on the road from London to Canterbury in search of insight into contemporary Britain.
Today he picks up his journey at a place steeped in English literature and empire.

Well, quite apart from Geoffrey Chaucer, the marshland here around me on the windswept northern coast of the county of Kent, where the Canterbury Road comes near to the estuary of the River Thames, is steeped in English literature.
Somerset Maugham lived nearby.
So did Joseph Conrad, who was then buried at Canterbury in 1924.

In fact, at the start of Conrad's classic book of empire, ""Heart of Darkness,"" he wrote of the River Thames right here: What greatness had not floated on the ebb of that river into the mystery of an unknown earth?
The dreams of men, the seed of commonwealth, the germs of empires.
But the writer whose spirit haunts this area more than any other is not Conrad, but Charles Dickens, who lived for decades nearby.

It was here in the marshes at Cooling that the memorable scene at the start of ""Great Expectations"" took place, when the young Pip had the meeting with the convict Magwitch that would change his life.
(Soundbite of school)
Hello.
Hello.
Hello.
You must be Sarah.
I am Sarah, yes.
Welcome to Gad's Hill School, formerly home of Charles Dickens.
Sarah Garratt is a teacher at Gad's Hill, which for more than 80 years has been a small private school housed in Charles Dickens' old house right on the Canterbury Road just outside Rochester.
Books overseen here at Gad's Hill: ""Tale of Two Cities,"" ""Great Expectations,"" and he died in - whilst he was writing ""The Mystery of Edwin Drood.

And this is the conservatory.
Good place for the children to have their lunch.
It is a fantastic place for the children to have their lunch.
We've got 400 kids, obviously not 400 in here at the moment.
So, is there a sort of process that scholarly osmosis whereby these children absorb this sort of genius of the great man?
Yeah, I would like to think so.
I mean, it's not something we put in our prospectus, you know, come here and you'll become a fantastic author.
